moves.1. e4 c5 2. f4: my preferred way, to tackle the Sicilian...
Blacks' position is solid: White has a little more space...
moves.11. Nbd2 Rfd8: enforcing d5: but d5 is no real threat to White, in this variation; e4-e5 is a sound reply...
moves.12. Qc2 e5: not sure, if this is the answer for Black...
moves.13. fxe5 Nxe5 14. d4 Nxf3+ 15. Bxf3: the only one: pawn e4 needs to be covered...
moves.16... h6 17. h4 Nh7 18. Bf2 g5 19. hxg5: both repositioning: the Kings need to get out of the way......
moves.25... Bc8 26. Rxh6: only just in time: I liked this better, then a direct Nh2; this would have shut off Rh1...
moves.26... Rxh6: pawn g4 is invulnerable for now: the threat of Rxh8 takes care of that...
moves.27... Ke8 28. g5: much stronger, then Nh2 at this point: White not only has won an important pawn, but is also cracking open Blacks' Kings' wing...
moves.28... Qd8: bringing the Black Queen into action again: a direct f6, is no real option; Black can now bring the King to safety via Kd7...
moves.29. Qd2: I took a short look at Qb3: but Bd7 eliminates all threats; for now, this is best: f6, g6!, is still no option for Black...
moves.29... b4: Black has no real moves: so he starts looking for little leaks, in the White position; this induces Ba6+...
moves.30. Nh4 Ba6+ 31. Ke1 bxc3 32. bxc3 Qb6 3: Qb1+ has to be taken care of: pawn g5 will hold for now...
moves.33... a4: still, f6, g6 is no option: Black is running out of good moves...
moves.34. Nf5 Qb5: this one caught me a little off guard: is Qd3 a problem, or not?
moves.35. Rg2: I decided, to give it a try...
moves.35... Qd3 36. Qxd3 Bxd3: the message is clear: Whites' center pawns will fall...
moves.39. Rb7+: the winning move: Black has to return to the bottom row, and lose Rg8 after Rb8+; so Black resigned...
